title: Quiz 6: Obstetric Emergencies
topicName: Unit Three Part Two : Abnormal Labour and Puerperium
description: Comprehensive test on managing critical emergencies like cord prolapse, PPH, uterine rupture, and shock.

questions.question: Prioritize the management steps for a Pulsating Cord Prolapse in First Stage of Labour:

items.text: Manually elevate the presenting part off the cord
Place mother in knee-chest or Trendelenburg position
Administer oxygen and start IV fluids

questions.explanation: Immediate relief of pressure is critical. Do not remove hand until delivery.
questions.hint: Relieve pressure -> Position -> Help -> Support -> Surgery.

questions.question: Primary Post Partum Haemorrhage is defined as blood loss > ___BLANK___ ml within ___BLANK___ hours of delivery.
questions.explanation: >500ml is PPH. Within 24hrs is Primary PPH.

questions.question: What are the signs of a Ruptured Uterus? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Rupture presents with tearing pain, shock, stopping of labour, and the baby moving up into the abdomen (recession).
questions.hint: Labour stops abruptly and the patient collapses.

questions.question: Match the Shoulder Dystocia manoeuvre to its action:

pairs.right: External pressure to dislodge anterior shoulder
Pushing posterior shoulder towards foetal chest

questions.explanation: McRoberts opens the pelvis. Suprapubic dislodges. Rubin's reduces diameter.

questions.question: Which degree of Uterine Inversion is described as 'The fundus reaches the internal os'?

richContent.content:
DegreeDescription
1stFundus at internal os
2ndBody inverted into vagina
3rdProlapse outside vulva

questions.explanation: First degree is the mildest form where the fundus dimples down to the cervix.
questions.hint: The start of the inversion process.

questions.question: Sudden dyspnoea, cyanosis, and collapse during or immediately after labour suggests:
questions.explanation: AFE typically presents with sudden respiratory collapse (hypoxia) and cardiovascular collapse.
questions.hint: Fluid entering the bloodstream causing blockage.

questions.question: Match the stage of shock to its physiological signs:
questions.explanation: Body compensates first (pulse up), then fails (BP down), then organs die.
questions.hint: Compensatory means the body is fighting back.

questions.question: In Vasa Praevia, if foetal bleeding is suspected, the management is immediate vaginal delivery.
questions.explanation: Vasa Praevia bleeding is foetal blood. Immediate Caesarean section is required to save the baby; vaginal delivery risks tearing the vessels further.
questions.hint: The baby is losing blood rapidly.

questions.question: Select the immediate management steps for Atonic Postpartum Haemorrhage (PPH). (Select all that apply)

options.text: Massage/Rub the uterus to contract it

questions.explanation: First-line management involves mechanical (massage, compression) and pharmacological (oxytocin) methods. Surgery is a last resort.

questions.question: Name the specific manoeuvre used to replace an acute inversion of the uterus manually.
questions.explanation: Johnson's Manoeuvre involves grasping the protruding fundus and pushing it up through the vagina.
